Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Angiotensin-2 vs. Noradrenaline in Cardiac Surgery

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults at elevated risk of AKI undergoing cardiac surgery.

Intervention.evidence: randomly allocated to receive either angiotensin-2 or noradrenaline

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the feasibility of using angiotensin-2 compared to noradrenaline to maintain peri-operative blood pressure and its impact on renal outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was feasibility, assessed by consent rate, protocol adherence, infusion duration, MAP maintenance, and major adverse outcomes.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via a REDCap database.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included participants, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty participants were randomised (28 to angiotensin-2, 32 to noradrenaline) between March and September 2021.

Result_Outcome.evidence: AKI occurred in 25% of the angiotensin-2 group and 38% of the noradrenaline group (p=0.31).

Harms.evidence: One stroke, one extracorporeal support, and three renal replacement therapies occurred in the noradrenaline group.

Trial_Registration.evidence: Australian and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry.
